headline: The Big Part of the Debt Ceiling Deal Congress Isn’t Talking About
text: Why the budget cuts in the debt ceiling deal are smaller than advertised.

text: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Another Early Morning Attack in Kyiv Kills 3
text: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia targeted the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, yet again with a missile attack in the early hours of Thursday, killing two women and a child who were not able to get into a closed shelter. Loud explosions were heard just minutes after air-raid sirens sounded throughout the city, waking residents worn out by a month of relentless attacks.

headline: McCarthy Emerges From the Debt Limit Fight With Victories, and Some Wounds
text: When the debt limit fight began, it was widely assumed that Speaker Kevin McCarthy, untested and inexperienced in high-stakes negotiations, would either preside over an economically and politically calamitous government default or lose his hard-won post in a right-wing mutiny after caving to Democrats.

headline: Where Is the Pass Going?
text: Few aspects of basketball capture the joy of the game like great passes. Can you see the court like the pros?

headline: Quotation of the Day: Amazon Employees Connect Over Working From Home
text: “It feels to me like kind of an eye-for-an-eye situation: You’re not helping anyone — you’re just hurting everyone.”

headline: Corrections: June 1, 2023
text: An article on Tuesday about a teen’s killing in North Dakota that became a right-wing talking point misstated the party registration of the parents of Shannon Brandt. Mr. Brandt’s parents are not registered with a political party. North Dakota does not have statewide voter registration. A picture caption with the article referred imprecisely to an argument between Mr. Brandt and Cayler Ellingson. While the two men were at Buck’s n Doe’s Bar & Grill before Mr. Ellingson’s death, it is not clear where the argument happened.

headline: Why New York Has Such Strange Rules About Alcohol
text: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Ever wonder why you can’t buy wine in a New York supermarket? Today we’ll look at the various regulations around selling alcohol in the city.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: A day after the first military strike to hit civilian areas in Moscow, Kremlin officials jumped on the refusal of Ukraine’s allies to condemn the attack as proof that Russia’s real war was with the West.

headline: Word of the Day: tentative
text: The word tentative has appeared in 250 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 2 in “Australia Aims to ‘Stamp Out’ Vaping With Sweeping Regulations” by Remy Tumin:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
text: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In the N.B.A. Playoffs, Flopping Is a Welcome Sideshow
text: In the 2023 N.B.A. playoffs, LeBron James got in on the act. And Stephen Curry, and the league’s most valuable player, Joel Embiid. Kyle Lowry keeps trying, but oh does he need help. Even Nikola Jokic has taken a bow.

headline: Stony Brook University to Receive $500 Million, an Uncommonly Large Gift
text: Stony Brook University, a public school on Long Island, received a donation of $500 million on Thursday from a foundation formed by an alumnus and a former faculty member, making it the recipient of one of the largest gifts to a university in American history.

headline: What Your Mustache Says About You
text: About six months ago, Micah Fitzerman-Blue, a screenwriter in Los Angeles, was shaving his beard when he reached the region between his nose and his upper lip and thought, What if I just stopped?

headline: The Balenciaga Comeback Is Happening
text: Demna, the mononymic designer of Balenciaga, that former harbinger of all things haute and cool that experienced a highly public fall from grace last winter, simply cannot resist a visual metaphor. His collections became famous as comments on the world around us and then infamous: He sent refugees trudging through a maelstrom after Russia invaded Ukraine; fetishized capitalism in the New York Stock Exchange; and then veered uncomfortably close to associating children with S&M when he posed a youngster amid adult “toys,” reminding the watching world that those who thrive by the viral image risk dying by it.

headline: Conflict With the Far Right Shrouds Jerusalem’s Pride Parade
text: One ultraconservative member of the Israeli government had pledged to abolish the Jerusalem Pride and Tolerance Parade. Another far-right minister with a history of homophobia, Itamar Ben-Gvir, who now oversees the police, was tasked with securing it.

headline: Republican Ex-Candidate Faces Federal Charges Over Shootings
text: Solomon Peña, a former Republican candidate for the New Mexico House of Representatives, has been charged with several federal offenses in connection with drive-by shootings at the homes of Democratic officials, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

headline: Death is Real. So Is Happiness. Imagine That.
text: How a childhood existential crisis led one man to the promise of happiness. The TV writer Eric Kaplan and the illustrator Francesco Chiacchio tell the tale.

headline: We Spoke With 5 People Who Work With A.I. Here’s What Keeps Them Up at Night.
text: Five A.I. practitioners — an industry godfather, an artist, an ethicist, a writer and a computer scientist — share their experiences working with artificial intelligence.

headline: At This Texas Campus Ministry, ‘Inclusive Love’ Is the Mission
text: Students at the University of Texas in Austin have found a safe haven at the Texas Wesley, a Methodist group whose doors are open to all.

headline: 36 Hours in Los Angeles
text: Locals know the best spots are hiding in plain sight in the City of Angels.

headline: Heading Uptown With $250,000 and Some Hope. Could They Afford a Co-op?
text: A couple searched in East Harlem and the Bronx for a modest new apartment that would allow them to entertain friends and commute easily to Midtown. Here’s what they found.

headline: Greetings From ‘Mexicoland’
text: Stepping through the ornate facade of a faux City Hall, I enter the indoor swap meet at Plaza Mexico, the kitschy shopping center that’s a landmark of California’s resurgent Latino identity. I’m in the town of Lynwood, but the vibe is nothing like the WASPy Los Angeles of my 1970s youth. At the traffic circle that serves as the Plaza’s entrance, I find a copy of the Angel of Independence, a famous monument in Mexico City that commemorates the beginning of Mexico’s fight for secession from Spain. The replica Mexican municipal building, or ayuntamiento, features the eagle and the serpent of Mexico’s coat of arms. This building was, in another time, a Montgomery Ward department store. Now I walk through it and enter the Latino equivalent of Disneyland.

headline: Congress Is Turning Climate Gaslighting Into Law
text: Late on Saturday, as members of Congress scrambled to strike a deal for legislation that would raise the nation’s debt ceiling, they agreed to a total non sequitur in the text they would release the next day. After a series of late-in-the-game interventions by lobbyists and energy executives, the draft bill declared the construction and operation of a natural gas pipeline to be “required in the national interest.” It wasn’t really germane to the debt ceiling, at least not in the literal sense. But then again, it wasn’t any ordinary pipeline.

headline: The New Terms of Abortion Politics
text: The Dobbs decision upended political calculations on both sides of the abortion debate. Democrats used the issue as evidence of Republican extremism, and it cost the G.O.P. seats in the 2022 midterms.

headline: What Biden Understands About Negotiating That Obama Never Did
text: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: What Belongs in Your Survival Kit, From 8 People Who Know Something About Disasters
text: Instant coffee, a stash of singles, a good rapport with your neighbors and … Pringles. Here’s what you really need to prepare for extreme weather events and other disasters.

headline: Millennials Are Not an Exception. They’ve Moved to the Right.
text: Fifteen years ago, a new generation of young voters propelled Barack Obama to a decisive victory that augured a new era of Democratic dominance.

headline: Mary Trump and E. Jean Carroll Are Collaborating on a Romance Novel. No Politics Allowed.
text: Earlier this year, Mary Trump, a niece and prominent critic of Donald J. Trump, had a bad bout of writer’s block. She was juggling several nonfiction projects and felt stuck, so she decided to write something completely different.

headline: Beyoncé and Jay-Z Join the $100 Million Home Club
text: Beyoncé and Jay-Z, no strangers to flashy real estate deals, reportedly upgraded from their $88 million mansion in Bel Air, Calif., to a $200 million Malibu property last month, officially erasing the line between going big and going home.

headline: China Investing in Open-Source Intelligence Collection on the U.S.
text: China’s intelligence agencies are investing deeply in open-source intelligence to learn more about the capabilities of the American military in the Pacific and beyond, according to a new report.

headline: Political Correctness Used to Be Funny. Now It’s No Joke.
text: Back in the early ’90s it would have been hard to imagine a time would come when people would long for double denim, the glumness of grunge and Ethan Hawke’s patchy “Reality Bites” facial hair. Yet more unfathomable: that there would be any affection for anything about that era’s nascent political correctness with its penchant for words like “womyn” and other idealistic but often ill-conceived efforts to reimagine the dictionary.

headline: S.A. Cosby Wishes More Writers Would Address the Fear of Success
text: Right now, there are three: “The Passenger,” by Cormac McCarthy, “The Hunt,” by Kelly J. Ford, and “Blue Like Me,” by Aaron Philip Clark. All three are incredible in different ways. “The Hunt” is an inventive serial killer thriller. “Blue Like Me” is an in-depth mystery that examines what it’s like being a police officer and a person of color. And “The Passenger” is classic McCarthy: inventive, insightful and sometimes surreal.

headline: Men Have Lost Their Way. Josh Hawley Has Thoughts About How to Save Them.
text: It’s the problem that has too many names.

headline: California’s Snow Is Melting, and It’s a Beautiful Thing
text: SODA SPRINGS, Calif. — My fellow Californians often remark that the weather in this state feels as if it has been reduced to two seasons, both defined by natural disasters: In summer and fall, huge, intense wildfires rip their way across dry land, and winter and early spring bring intense atmospheric rivers with heavy rainfall, floods and landslides, along with winds that take down trees.

headline: Dave Eggers Wants Readers to See How the Sausage Is Made
text: Consider the books that lived in the classrooms of your youth. Didn’t it seem like those stories materialized as if by magic, complete with illustrations, a title and a sturdy hardcover? There wasn’t a lot of discussion about how a book arrived in the world, or the arduous creative process behind every collection of words on a page — not just the ones lucky enough to snag an ISBN.

headline: Talk of Racism Proves Thorny for G.O.P. Candidates of Color
text: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina opened his presidential candidacy with a story of the nation’s bitter, racist past. It is one that he tells often, of a grandfather forced from school in the third grade to pick cotton in the Jim Crow South.

headline: X-Ray Vision Brings New Life to a Fossil Flattened by Time
text: While exploring an Arctic mountaintop in 2008, paleontologists unearthed a small skeleton that resembled a coiled sea serpent imprinted into a slab of 240 million-year-old rock. The remarkably complete skeleton, nicknamed Oda, was deposited in the collection of the University of Oslo’s Natural History Museum.

headline: Iceland Is a Magnet for Tourists. Its First Lady Has Some Advice for Them.
text: In July 2017, Eliza Reid and her husband celebrated their wedding anniversary with a romantic dinner in Reykjavik, Iceland. It was a summer evening, lots of people were out, and Ms. Reid suggested they go for a stroll after their meal. But her husband — Gudni Johannesson, the country’s president — didn’t feel up to facing a crowd asking for selfies.

headline: The Inspirations Behind ‘Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse’
text: In the 2018 animated hit “Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse,” Miles Morales, a Brooklyn teenage superhero in development, receives multiple unexpected visits from other dimensions. For the film’s sequel, “Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse,” it’s Morales (voiced by Shameik Moore) who must follow Gwen Stacy (Hailee Steinfeld), a version of Spider-Woman, into new realms where other spider people exist.

headline: I’m on Strike With the W.G.A. I Owe My Father at Least That Much.
text: Most discussion of the Hollywood writers’ strike has centered on money: the studio chiefs, tech demigods and private equity oligarchs who have it and the writers like me whose labor should entitle us to a greater share of it. As a member of the Writers Guild of America, whose strike will enter its second month this week, I think that discussion is important, but it misses the real point of why workers strike and why we’re willing to use the only leverage we’ve got — our livelihoods — in such a fight.

headline: The Newest High-End Amenity: Houses That Come With Horses
text: Plenty of luxury housing developments are built around glamorous perks: a manicured 18-hole golf course, a private beach club, even an exclusive on-site restaurant crowned with Michelin stars. Tucked in the coastal jungle of Western Mexico comes yet another hyper-luxurious real estate offering, this one banking on a novel perk: a pony named Karen.

headline: Haiti Has Overcome Other Crises. This Time, We Can’t Do It Alone.
text: As an infectious disease doctor working in Haiti for over 40 years, I have wrestled with countless tragedies. I have battled problems like H.I.V., tuberculosis, Covid-19, earthquakes, hurricanes and floods. Each time, our community of health care providers, police officers, humanitarian workers, government officials and citizens have pulled together and come up with a solution to steer Haitians to safety.

headline: 9 New Books Coming in June
text: In 1838, a group of powerful Jesuit priests sold 272 enslaved people to help secure the financial future of a pre-eminent Catholic school: the university now known as Georgetown. Swarns, a journalism professor and a contributing writer for The Times, builds on earlier reporting to show how the history of the Catholic Church in the United States is inextricably linked to slavery, and traces one family for nearly 200 years, starting with Ann Joice, a Black woman who arrived in Maryland in the 1600s as an indentured servant.

headline: In California’s Heartland, a New Resistance Movement Is Taking Root
text: Driving down the last steep grade of Tejon Pass, you come upon a fold in the earth of middle California where the tentacles of Los Angeles end and a new place begins. If you’ve never made the trip, the crossing is one of the true demarcations in the American landscape, the West’s Mason-Dixon line, though you won’t discern it at first because the plain below hides under a cover of soot and smog.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Slides to Lowest in More Than a Year
text: Inflation in the eurozone slid last month to the lowest level in more than a year, as an easing of price rises after last year’s run-up in energy bills gained momentum. But the price of food and services climbed at an uncomfortable pace, raising the odds that the European Central Bank will continue to lift interest rates to curb costs.

headline: Australia’s ‘Trial of the Century’ Stains Its Most Decorated Soldier
text: The case had been called Australia’s trial of the century. And though it centered on a claim of defamation, it grappled with a more consequential question: Was the country’s most decorated living soldier a war criminal?

headline: What It Takes to Protect Kyiv From Russian Bombardment
text: Find it, target it, shoot it.
